APP.TITLE: 子供のためのマシーンラーニング

ABOUT.TITLE: 子供のためのマシーンラーニング

WHAT.TITLE: 狙い
WHAT.BODY:
本ツールは、機械学習システムをトレーニングし、それを元にアプリを構築するという実際の経験を通して機械学習の基礎を学ぶためのものです。

文字や数字を分類したり、画像を判断するための機械学習モデルをトレーニングする、簡単に使える、ガイド付きの環境を提供します。

本ツールは子供たちにプログラミングを教えるための既存の多くの努力の上に構築されています。広くプログラミング教育用に使われているプラットフォームであるScratchにこれらの機械学習モデルを追加することで、子供たちがプロジェクトやゲームを彼らがトレーニングした機会学習のモデルを使って構築できるようにしています。

より詳細な情報は、以下を参照下さい:

WHY.TITLE: Why?
WHY.BODY:
機械学習システムは身近ないたるところにあり、毎日使っています。例えば、スパムフィルター、推奨エンジン、翻訳サービス、チャットボットとデジタルアシスタント、検索エンジン、そして不正検出システムなどです。

近い内に、機械学習システムが私たちの車を運転したり、私たちの病気を治すお医者さんを手伝うことが普通になるでしょう。

子供たちが私たちの世界がどのようにして機能しているのかを理解することは大切なことです。その能力や関連性を理解する最も良い方法は、彼ら自身がこの技術を用いて何かを作ってみることです。

より詳細な情報は、以下を読んでください。: '子供のための機械学習入門(英語)'

TECH.TITLE: 技術
TECH.BODY:
このツールは全てWebベースで、使うためにソフトウェアの導入や複雑な設定等は不要です。

学校やボランティアが運営する子ど向けのプログラミンググループで使われるようにデザインしており、先生やグループリーダーが、生徒のアクセスを管理できるように管理者用ページも提供します。

本システムはIBM Watson Developer CloudのAPIを利用してDale Laneが構築しました。

UPDATES.TITLE: ニュースと更新情報
UPDATES.DESCRIPTION: @MLforKidsからのニュースと更新情報

MENTIONS.TITLE: メディアで取り上げられました
MENTIONS.DESCRIPTION: wakelet.comから取り込んだメディア情報

ERRORS.PAGENOTFOUND: ページが見つかりません
ERRORS.NOTLOGGEDIN: ログインしていません
ERRORS.MISSINGPROJECTID: プロジェクトidがありません。戻って
ERRORS.IFPERSISTENT: もし、継続的にこの問題が起こる場合は、

WELCOME.TITLE: コンピューターにゲームの遊び方を教える
WELCOME.PROJECT_LABEL: あなたのプロジェクトに移動
WELCOME.STEP_1_TEXT: あなたが認識できるようにしたい物の例を集める
WELCOME.STEP_2_TEXT: 例を使って、コンピューターがそれらを認識できるようにトレーニングする
WELCOME.STEP_3_TEXT: Scratchでコンピューターがそれらを認識できる機能を使ったゲームを作る

LOGIN.TITLE: 機械学習をはじめよう
LOGIN.WELCOME: ようこそ、あなたが子供のためのマシーンラーニングのシステムにログインするアカウントを持つことに興味をがあるのは素晴らしいことです。
LOGIN.ALREADY_LOGGEDIN: 情報: ログイン済みです
LOGIN.ERROR_HELP: もし、継続して起こるようならヘルプを参照ください。
LOGIN.WHY_REGISTER_INTRO_1: アカウントを作ったり、登録しなくても子供のためのマシーンラーニングを使うことはできます。しかし、登録すると複数の追加機能を利用できるようになります。
LOGIN.WHY_REGISTER_INTRO_2: 登録せずに "お試し"で使った場合と登録してアカウントを作った場合で、できることの違いを以下の表にまとめています。
LOGIN.FORGOT_DETAILS: 詳細をわすれましたか?
LOGIN.TEACHER: 先生又はコーディンククラブのリーダー
LOGIN.FORGOT_TEXT: ユーザ名かパスワードを忘れた? 大丈夫、私たちはたまに忘れます。

TEACHER.TITLE: あなたは先生か、コーディングクラブのリーダーですか?
TEACHER.INFO1: もし、あなたの生徒のためにアクセスが必要な場合は、以下のクラスアカウントを作成してください。
TEACHER.INFO2: クラスアカウントは、誰が設定したかで２種類に分かれます。

UNMANAGED.TITLE: 管理しないクラスアカウントを作成する
UNMANAGED.INTRO: あなた自身でクラスアカウントを設定し、管理する場合は、今作成できます。
UNMANAGED.LISTINTRO: あなたは以下を実施する必要があります:
UNMANAGED.LIST_CREATEACCOUNT: IBM Cloudにアカウントを作成する
UNMANAGED.LIST_CREATEAPIKEYS: 機械学習モデルをトレイニングするために必要なWatson cloud サービスのAPI key(s)を作成する
UNMANAGED.LIST_ENTERAPIKEYS: この子供のためのマシーンラーニングツールにAPI keys　を入力する
UNMANAGED.HELP: ステップ毎のスクリーンショット付きの上記全ての操作手順はこちら

MANAGED.TITLE: 管理されるクラスアカウントの作成
MANAGED.INTRO: もし、Daleにクラスアカウントの設定をして欲しい場合は、以下のボタンを使て以下の情報をemailで送信してください。
MANAGED.LIST_NUMBEROFSTUDENTS: 必要となる生徒用アカウントの大凡の数
MANAGED.LIST_NAMEOFSCHOOL: アカウントを設定する学校、又はコーディンググループの名前

PROJECTS.TITLE: あなたの機械学習プロジェクト
PROJECTS.ADDNEWPROJECT: 新しいプロジェクトの追加
PROJECTS.CREATEFIRSTPROJECT: 最初のプロジェクトを作成するには右の 'プラス' ボタンをクリックしてください。

NEWPROJECT.TITLE: 新しい機械学習プロジェクトの開始

PROJECT_NAME.TITLE: プロジェクト名
PROJECT_NAME.NOTES: コンピュータに何を認識させたいのかが分かるようなプロジェクトの名前を付けましょう。

WHOLE_CLASS_PROJECT.TITLE: クラス全体のプロジェクトですか?
WHOLE_CLASS_PROJECT.NOTES_1: もし、クラス全員でこのプロジェクトに取り組めるようにしたいときには、ここをマークしてください。
WHOLE_CLASS_PROJECT.NOTES_2: これは、機械学習プロジェクトのトレーニングのやり方としてのクラウドソーシングを教える際には有用です。

TYPES.LABEL: 認識させる
TYPES.NOTES_1: どんなタイプの情報をコンピュータに認識させたいですか?
TYPES.NOTES_2: 単語、文章、パラグラフは、"text"を選んでください。
TYPES.NOTES_3: 写真、図、図形は、"images"を選んでください。
TYPES.NOTES_4: 数字のあつまりや、複数選択肢は、"numbers"を選択してください。

LANGUAGE.LABEL: 使用言語
LANGUAGE.NOTES: このプロジェクトでは何語を利用しますか?

NEWFIELD.DESCRIBE_FIELD: この項目にその値を説明する名前を付けてください。
NEWFIELD.MULTICHOICE: 複数の選択肢から選ぶのであれば、"multiple-choice"を選んでください。
NEWFIELD.ADD_FIRST_FIELD: 選択肢を複数選択肢のリストに入力して、Enterを押してください。
NEWFIELD.ADD_ANOTHER_FIELD: 他の選択肢を複数選択肢のリストに入力して、Enterを押してください。

NEWVALUE.ADD_FIRST_VALUE: コンピューターをトレーニングするそれそれの例に含まれる値を'Add a value'ボタンをクリックして説明することから始めてください。
NEWVALUE.VALUES_LIMIT: 一つのプロジェクトで扱える値の種類は最大１０です。

TRAIN.TITLE: トレーニング
TRAIN.BODY: コンピューターに認識させたい例を収集してください。

LEARNANDTEST.TITLE: 学習 & テスト
LEARNANDTEST.BODY: 例を使ってコンピューターが認識できるようにトレーニングします。

MAKES.TITLE: プログラム作成
MAKES.BODY: あなたがトレーニングした機械学習モデルを用いて、ScratchやPythonでゲームやアプリを作成する。

SCRATCH.TITLE: Scratch
SCRATCH.BODY: あなたがトレーニングした機械学習モデルを使って、Scratchアプリを作る。

PYTHON.TITLE: Python
PYTHON.BODY: Pythonプログラムで、あなたがトレーニングした機械学習モデルを使う。

APPINVENTOR.TITLE: アプリ開発者
APPINVENTOR.BODY: あなたの機械学習モデルを用いたモバイルアプリを作成する。

SCRATCH3.TITLE: Scratch 3
SCRATCH3.BODY: Scratchの新しい版であなたの機械学習モデルを使ったアプリを作成する。

TRAINING.TITLE: トレーニング
TRAINING.CREATEFIRSTLABEL: 最初のグループを追加するには、右側にある 'plus' ボタンをクリックしてください。
TRAINING.CROWDSOURCEDEMPTY: 先生がトレーニング用のグループを作成後に、このページをリフレッシュしてください。
TRAINING.DRAGIMAGES: 画像をブラウザの他画面からドラッグし、ここに落としてください。

NEWLABEL.INTRO: 認識する新しいラベルを入力してください。
NEWLABEL.ERROR: ラベルは英数字のみ利用できます。

NEWEXAMPLE.INTRO: 例を入力してください。
NEWEXAMPLE.INTROURL: 例の画像のURLを入力してください。
NEWEXAMPLE.INTROWEBCAM: 新しい例を追加してください。
NEWEXAMPLE.ERROR: タブや改行は利用できません。
NEWEXAMPLE.REQUIRED: 例の全ての項目に値を入れる必要があります。
NEWEXAMPLE.PATTERNNUMBER: 数字のようではないのですが
NEWEXAMPLE.PATTERNURL: 画像のWebアドレスである必要があります。
NEWEXAMPLE.WEBCAMFAIL: 失礼! webcamが動作するようにできません。
NEWEXAMPLE.WEBCAMERROR: あなたのWebブラウザから受け取ったメッセージは、:

MODELS.TITLE: 機械学習モデル
MODELS.TRAIN: 新しい機械学習モデルをトレーニングする

WHATHAVEYOUDONE.TITLE: 何をしましたか?
WHATHAVEYOUDONE.PLEASEWAIT: 通常２，３分かかりますが、コンピューターが忙しい時には、それより長くかかることがあります。
WHATHAVEYOUDONE.FAIL: 残念ながら、何か上手く行きませんでした。

CROWDSOURCED.TEXT: あなたのクラスは、あなた方が収集したテキストの例を用いて機械学習モデルをトレーニングしています。
CROWDSOURCED.IMAGES: あなたのクラスは、あなた方が収集した画像の例を用いて機械学習モデルをトレーニングしています。
CROWDSOURCED.NUMBERS: あなたのクラスは、あなた方が収集した数値の例を用いて機械学習モデルをトレーニングしています。

INDIVIDUAL.TEXT: あなたは、あなたが収集した文字列の例を用いて機械学習モデルをトレーニングを既に始めています。
INDIVIDUAL.IMAGES: あなたは、あなたが収集した画像の例を用いて機械学習モデルをトレーニングを既に始めています。
INDIVIDUAL.NUMBERS: あなたは、あなたが収集した数値の例を用いて機械学習モデルをトレーニングを既に始めています。

CLASS.IMAGES: あなたの先生は、あなた方のクラスが収集した画像を認識するように機械学習モデルのトレーニングを試みました。
CLASS.NUMBERS: あなたの先生は、あなた方のクラスが収集した数値を認識するように機械学習モデルのトレーニングを試みました。

YOU.TEXT: あなたは、あなたが収集した文字列を認識するように機械学習モデルのトレーニングを試みました。
YOU.IMAGES: あなたは、あなたが収集した画像を認識するように機械学習モデルのトレーニングを試みました。
YOU.NUMBERS: あなた、あなたが収集した数値を認識するように機械学習モデルのトレーニングを試みました。

INDIVIDUAL.TEXT: あなたは、あなたが収集した文字列を認識するように機械学習モデルのトレーニングを試みました。
INDIVIDUAL.IMAGES: あなたは、あなたが収集した画像を認識するように機械学習モデルのトレーニングを試みました。
INDIVIDUAL.NUMBERS: あなた、あなたが収集した数値を認識するように機械学習モデルのトレーニングを試みました。

CROWDSOURCED.TEXT: あなたのクラスは、あなたが文字列の例を収集したいと言いました。
CROWDSOURCED.IMAGES: あなたのクラスは、あなたが画像の例を収集したいと言いました。
CROWDSOURCED.NUMBERS: あなたのクラスは、あなたが数値の例を収集したいと言いました。

INDIVIDUAL.TEXT: あなたは、あなたが文字列の例を収集したいと言っていました。
INDIVIDUAL.IMAGES: あなたは、あなたが画像の例を収集したいと言っていました。
INDIVIDUAL.NUMBERS: あなたは、あなたが数値の例を収集したいと言っていました。

CROWDSOURCED.TEXT: あなたのクラスは、文字列が以下の時に、コンピューターが認識できるようにするために、あなたが文字列の例を集めたいと言いました。
CROWDSOURCED.IMAGES: あなたのクラスは、画像が以下の時に、コンピューターが認識できるようにするために、あなたが画像の例を集めたいと言いました。
CROWDSOURCED.NUMBERS: あなたのクラスは、数値が以下の時に、コンピューターが認識できるようにするために、あなたが数値の例を集めたいと言いました。

INDIVIDUAL.TEXT: You said that you want to collect examples of text for a computer to recognise when text is
INDIVIDUAL.IMAGES: You said that you want to collect examples of images for a computer to recognise when images are
INDIVIDUAL.NUMBERS: You said that you want to collect examples of numbers for a computer to recognise when numbers are

NOEXAMPLES.CLASS: So far, your class haven't collected any examples yet.
NOEXAMPLES.YOU: So far, you haven't collected any examples yet.

CROWDSOURCED.TEXT: Your class has collected examples of text for a computer to use to recognise when text is
CROWDSOURCED.IMAGES: Your class has collected examples of images for a computer to use to recognise when images are
CROWDSOURCED.NUMBERS: Your class has collected examples of numbers for a computer to use to recognise when numbers are

INDIVIDUAL.TEXT: You have collected examples of text for a computer to use to recognise when text is
INDIVIDUAL.IMAGES: You have collected examples of images for a computer to use to recognise when images are
INDIVIDUAL.NUMBERS: You have collected examples of numbers for a computer to use to recognise when numbers are

WHATSNEXT.TITLE: What's next?
WHATSNEXT.PLEASEWAIT: You could wait for the machine learning model to finish being trained.
WHATSNEXT.OFFERQUIZ: Or, you could try the machine learning quiz below, to check what you've learned.
WHATSNEXT.FAIL: The error message from the training computer is shown below. If that makes sense to you, try and fix the problem. Otherwise, it might be worth trying again in case it was just a random error.

IDLE.NOLABELS: The next step is to go to the Train page. Add some labels for each of the things that you want to teach the computer to be able to recognise.

ONELABEL.EXPLANATION: You've only said one thing that you want the computer to be able to recognise: {{ label }}
ONELABEL.ISTHATALL: Is that the only thing you want the computer to be able to recognise?
ONELABEL.NO:
No?
Go back to the Train page.
Add more labels for each of the things that you want to teach the computer to be able to recognise.
ONELABEL.YES:
Yes?
You need to do a little more work first.
For the computer to be able to learn how to recognise "{{ label }}", you need to give it some examples of things that aren't {{ label }}.
Go back to the Train page and create a new label for examples of things that aren't {{ label }}. You could call it "not-{{ label }}".

LABELS.NO_DATA: The next step is to go to the Train page. Add examples for each of the labels.

MORE_EXAMPLES.YOU: Go back to the Train page and collect more examples for each of the labels.
MORE_EXAMPLES.CLASS: Ask your class to go back to the Train page and collect more examples for each of the labels.

MORE_DATA.MORE_IS_BETTER: The more you can get, the better it should learn, but you need at least {{ minimumExamples }} examples of each as an absolute minimum.

ENOUGH_DATA.READY_TO_START: Ready to start the computer's training?

START_TRAINING.CROWDSOURCED: Click the button below to start training a machine learning model using the examples your class have collected so far
START_TRAINING.INDIVIDUAL: Click the button below to start training a machine learning model using the examples you have collected so far

MORE_EXAMPLES.CROWDSOURCED: (Or ask your class to go back to the Train page if you want them to collect more examples first.)
MORE_EXAMPLES.INDIVIDUAL: (Or go back to the Train page if you want to collect some more examples first.)

ENOUGH_DATA.WAITING_FOR_TEACHER: Waiting for your teacher to start the computer's training.

TEST.TEXT: Try testing the machine learning model below. Enter an example of text below, that you didn't include in the examples you used to train it. It will tell you what it recognises it as, and how confident it is in that.
TEST.IMAGES: Try testing the machine learning model below. Enter an example image below, that you didn't include in the examples you used to train it. It will tell you what it recognises it as, and how confident it is in that.
TEST.NUMBERS: Try testing the machine learning model below. Enter an example of numbers below, that you didn't include in the examples you used to train it. It will tell you what it recognises it as, and how confident it is in that.

READY.SCRATCH: If the computer seems to have learned to recognise things correctly, then you can go to Scratch and use what the computer has learned to make a game!

MORE_EXAMPLES.CROWDSOURCED: If the computer is getting too many things wrong, your class might want to go back to the Train page and collect some more examples.
MORE_EXAMPLES.INDIVIDUAL: If the computer is getting too many things wrong, you might want to go back to the Train page and collect some more examples

RETRAIN.YOU: Once you've done that, click on the button below to train a new machine learning model and see what difference the extra examples will make!
RETRAIN.CLASS: Once you've done that, your teacher will need to train a new machine learning model.

TRAINING.TITLE: Info from training computer:
TRAINING.DELETION: Model will automatically be deleted after:
TRAINING.PROMPTREFRESH: If this is more than a minute, you should refresh the page to get an up-to-date status

INTRO.TEXT: Try putting in some text to see how it is recognised based on your training.
INTRO.IMAGES: Try putting in an image to see how it is recognised based on your training.
INTRO.NUMBERS: Try putting in some numbers to see how it is recognised based on your training.

QUIZ.TITLE: Quiz time!
QUIZ.INTROQUESTION: While you are waiting for the model to finish training, try answering this question.
QUIZ.PREVIOUSLY_ATTEMPTED: You've seen this one before - let's see if you remember what the right answer is this time!
QUIZ.INCORRECT_ANSWER: No, sorry. The correct answer is shown above.

MAKES.TITLE: Make something with your machine learning model
MAKES.SCRATCH2: Make a project in the current version of Scratch
MAKES.SCRATCH3: Use the new (beta) version of Scratch
MAKES.PYTHON: Write Python code to use your machine learning model
MAKES.APPINVENTOR: Make a mobile app for your phone or tablet

PYTHON.TITLE: Using machine learning in Python
PYTHON.NOTREADY: Your project isn't ready to be used in Python yet.
PYTHON.NOMODEL: You haven't trained a machine learning model yet.

APPINVENTOR.TITLE: Using machine learning in App Inventor
APPINVENTOR.NOTREADY: Your project isn't ready to be used in App Inventor yet.
APPINVENTOR.NOMODEL: You haven't trained a machine learning model yet.
APPINVENTOR.BETAWARNING: This is an early beta. Support for App Inventor is not finished, and will probably have a few bugs and problems.

SCRATCH.TITLE: Using machine learning in Scratch
SCRATCH.NOTREADY: Your project isn't ready to be used in Scratch yet.
SCRATCH.NOMODEL: You haven't trained a machine learning model yet.
SCRATCH.LAUNCH_SCRATCH_BY_ITSELF: (You can use Scratch by itself if you want.)
SCRATCH.GO_TO_LEARNANDTEST: Or go to the Learn & Test page for some tips on what to do next.
SCRATCH.MORE_BLOCKS: Your project will add these blocks to the More Blocks tab in Scripts.
SCRATCH.EXPLAIN_RECOGNISE_LABEL: Put {{ type }} in the input for this, and it will return the label that your machine learning model recognises it as.
SCRATCH.EXPLAIN_RECOGNISE_CONFIDENCE: This will return how confident your machine learning model is that it recognises the type of {{ type }}. (As a number from 0 - 100).
SCRATCH.EXPLAIN_LABELS: These blocks represent the labels you've created in your project, so you can use their names in your scripts.
SCRATCH.EXPLAIN_COSTUMEIMAGE: This block is in the Looks palette for Sprites and will return the image of the currently selected costume.
SCRATCH.SAMPLE_SCRIPT: This means you can do something like this:
SCRATCH.SAMPLE_SCREENSHOT: It will look something like this - except with the name of your project.
SCRATCH.EXPLAIN_STATUS: The coloured circle next to your project name tells you if your machine learning model is okay.
SCRATCH.STATUS_GREEN: means your model is trained and ready to go
SCRATCH.STATUS_YELLOW: means your model hasn't finished training yet
SCRATCH.STATUS_RED: means something went wrong. Go back to the Learn & Test page to see what went wrong with training.

WORKSHEETS.TITLE: Machine learning projects
WORKSHEETS.INTRO_1: These projects are downloadable step-by-step guides, with explanations and colour screenshots for students to follow.
WORKSHEETS.INTRO_2: Each project is a stand-alone activity, written to last for a single lesson, and will guide children to create a game or interactive project that demonstrates a real-world use of artificial intelligence and machine learning.
WORKSHEETS.INTRO_3: Suggestions for new worksheets, suggestions of improvements to any of the worksheets, or contributions of new project worksheets, are all very welcome.

MAKETYPES.SCRATCH_WORKSHEET: Worksheet for making project in Scratch
MAKETYPES.PYTHON_WORKSHEET: Worksheet for making project in Python
MAKETYPES.APPINVENTOR_WORKSHEET: Worksheet for making project in App Inventor

NO_WORKSHEETS.NO_MATCHES: There aren't any project worksheets that match those filters.
NO_WORKSHEETS.MAKE_YOUR_OWN: You could adapt some of the existing worksheets or come up with a new one.
NO_WORKSHEETS.CONTRIBUTE: If you do, please consider contributing it for others to use.

SMARTCLASSROOM.TITLE: Smart Classroom
SMARTCLASSROOM.SUMMARY: Teach a computer to recognise the meaning of your commands
SMARTCLASSROOM.DESCRIPTION: Create a smart assistant in Scratch that lets you control virtual devices.

MAKEMEHAPPY.TITLE: Make me happy
MAKEMEHAPPY.SUMMARY: Teach a computer to recognise compliments and insults
MAKEMEHAPPY.DESCRIPTION: Create a character in Scratch that smiles if you say nice things to it and cries if you say mean things to it.

SNAP.TITLE: Snap!
SNAP.SUMMARY: Teach a computer to recognise what icons look like
SNAP.DESCRIPTION: Make a card game in Scratch that learns to recognise pictures of your card.

CHAMELEON.TITLE: Chameleon
CHAMELEON.SUMMARY: Teach a computer to recognise colours
CHAMELEON.DESCRIPTION: Make a chameleon in Scratch that changes colour to match its background

MAILMANMAX.TITLE: Mailman Max
MAILMANMAX.SUMMARY: Teach a computer to recognise handwriting
MAILMANMAX.DESCRIPTION: Make a postal sorting office in Scratch that can recognise handwritten postcodes on envelopes.

CARORCUP.TITLE: Car or cup
CARORCUP.SUMMARY: Teach a computer to recognise pictures of objects
CARORCUP.DESCRIPTION: Train the computer to be able to sort photos into groups.

FACELOCK.TITLE: Face Lock
FACELOCK.SUMMARY: Teach a computer to recognise faces
FACELOCK.DESCRIPTION: Make a phone in Scratch that unlocks if it recognises your face.

JOURNEYTOSCHOOL.TITLE: Journey to school
JOURNEYTOSCHOOL.SUMMARY: Teach a computer to make predictions
JOURNEYTOSCHOOL.DESCRIPTION: Train the computer to be able to predict how you travel to school in the morning.

SHYPANDA.TITLE: Shy Panda
SHYPANDA.SUMMARY: Teach a computer to recognise pictures
SHYPANDA.DESCRIPTION: Make a dancing panda that gets shy and stops dancing if it sees you looking.

VIRTUALPET.TITLE: Virtual Pet
VIRTUALPET.SUMMARY: Teach a computer to recognise pictures
VIRTUALPET.DESCRIPTION: Train the computer to recognise what you're doing so you can look after a virtual pet.

PACMAN.TITLE: Pac-Man
PACMAN.SUMMARY: Teach a computer to play a game
PACMAN.DESCRIPTION: Create a Pac-Man game in Scratch that learns how to avoid the ghost.

CHATBOTS.TITLE: Chatbots
CHATBOTS.SUMMARY: Teach a computer to recognise questions
CHATBOTS.DESCRIPTION: Create a chatbot that can answer questions about a topic of your choice.

TOURISTINFO.TITLE: Tourist Info
TOURISTINFO.SUMMARY: Teach a computer to make recommendations
TOURISTINFO.DESCRIPTION: Create a mobile app in Scratch that recommends tourist attractions based on people's interests.

SORTINGHAT.TITLE: Sorting Hat
SORTINGHAT.SUMMARY: Teach a computer to recognise use of language
SORTINGHAT.DESCRIPTION: Create a Sorting Hat like in Harry Potter, that puts you in a school House based on what you say.

ROCKPAPERSCISSORS.TITLE: Rock, Paper, Scissors
ROCKPAPERSCISSORS.SUMMARY: Teach a computer to recognise shapes
ROCKPAPERSCISSORS.DESCRIPTION: Make a Rock, Paper, Scissors game in Scratch that learns to recognise hand shapes.

JUDGEABOOK.TITLE: Judge a book
JUDGEABOOK.SUMMARY: Teach a computer to recognise visual style
JUDGEABOOK.DESCRIPTION: Make a game in Scratch to test whether it really is possible to judge a book by its cover.

LOCATELARRY.TITLE: Locate Larry
LOCATELARRY.SUMMARY: Teach a computer to find something in a picture
LOCATELARRY.DESCRIPTION: Make a "Where's Wally?"-style game in Scratch, and teach the computer to find your character.

CONFUSED.TITLE: Confused
CONFUSED.SUMMARY: Teach a computer to recognise fruit
CONFUSED.DESCRIPTION: Learn about how computers can be confused and can make mistakes if they're trained badly.

SCHOOLLIBRARY.TITLE: School Library
SCHOOLLIBRARY.SUMMARY: Teach a computer to make recommendations
SCHOOLLIBRARY.DESCRIPTION: Create a school librarian in Scratch that suggests who a reading book might be suitable for.

WHATTWITTERTHINKS.TITLE: What does Twitter think?
WHATTWITTERTHINKS.SUMMARY: Teach a computer to measure public opinion
WHATTWITTERTHINKS.DESCRIPTION: Create a sentiment analysis tool in Scratch to analyze discussion on Twitter

NOUGHTSANDCROSSES.TITLE: Noughts & Crosses
NOUGHTSANDCROSSES.SUMMARY: Teach a computer to play a game
NOUGHTSANDCROSSES.DESCRIPTION: Create a noughts and crosses game in Scratch that learns how to beat you.

TOPTRUMPS.TITLE: Top Trumps
TOPTRUMPS.SUMMARY: Teach a computer to play a game
TOPTRUMPS.DESCRIPTION: Train a computer to be able to play the Top Trumps card game in Scratch.

HEADLINES.TITLE: Headlines
HEADLINES.SUMMARY: Test the computer's ability to recognise use of language
HEADLINES.DESCRIPTION: Train a computer to recognise headlines from national newspapers.

RESTRICTIONS.TITLE: Restrictions
RESTRICTIONS.DESCRIPTION: Review limits and restrictions that apply to your class

APIKEYS.TITLE: API Keys
APIKEYS.DESCRIPTION: Set up IBM Watson credentials to enable your class to create machine learning models

STUDENTS.TITLE: Students
STUDENTS.DESCRIPTION: Create, reset and delete logins for students in your class

SUPERVISION.TITLE: Supervision
SUPERVISION.DESCRIPTION: Review projects that your students have created

DELETECLASS.TITLE: Delete class
DELETECLASS.DESCRIPTION: This will delete the accounts for you and all of the students in your class

CANYOUHELP.TITLE: Can you help?

MENU.NOTAUTHORISED: You are not authorized to access the teacher page for your class.

APIKEYS.TITLE: Administration : IBM Watson API Keys
APIKEYS.NO_TEXT_CREDENTIALS: You don't have any Assistant credentials. This means that it will not be possible to train models for text projects.
APIKEYS.NO_IMAGE_CREDENTIALS: You don't have any Visual Recognition API keys. This means that it will not be possible to train models for images projects.
APIKEYS.NOTAUTHORISED: You are not authorized to access the Watson API keys used by your class.
APIKEYS.MANAGEDCLASS: API Keys used by your class are being managed for you.
APIKEYS.HELP_STEPBYSTEP_GUIDE: If you're not sure what to do here, please follow the step-by-step guide . If you'd like any help, please get in touch.
APIKEYS.INTRO_WATSONASSISTANT: Training machine learning models for text projects uses Watson Assistant
APIKEYS.INTRO_VISUALRECOGNITION: Training machine learning models for images projects uses Watson Visual Recognition
APIKEYS.ERROR_FETCHING_WATSONASSISTANT: Failed to get your Watson Assistant passwords
APIKEYS.ERROR_FETCHING_VISUALRECOG: Failed to get your Visual Recognition API keys

APIKEYS.LIMIT_IMAGE_PROJECTS: Number of images machine learning models your students can have:

HELP.CONTACT: If you have any problems or questions, please email Dale.Lane@uk.ibm.com

GETTINGSTARTED.TITLE: Getting started?
GETTINGSTARTED.INTRO: Download a PDF with a short getting started guide:
GETTINGSTARTED.MANAGEDEXPL: For school teachers, coding group leaders, or other volunteers
GETTINGSTARTED.UNMANAGEDEXPL: For IBM employees, or teachers and coding group leaders who manage their own class accounts

FAQS.TITLE: Want to know more?
FAQS.INTRO2: The list below contains the questions and issues that I hear about most often. If you see something that looks similar to your problem, click on the summary for more info.
FAQS.INTRO3: If you're still stuck, or you've run into a problem I've not included in the list, sorry! Please email me or create an issue report so that I can help.

SCRATCH.TITLE: Scratch issues
SCRATCH.Q1: I don't know how to get Scratch working
SCRATCH.Q1-A-1: Machine Learning for Kids uses Scratch 2. Scratch needs Adobe Flash to work, so you need to be using an operating system and a web browser that can work with Flash (so that means no iPads for now, sorry).
SCRATCH.Q1-A-2: If you're not sure about how to enable Flash, you can download a document with some tips for getting Scratch working.
SCRATCH.Q2: The "Load Project" and "Save Project" menus in Scratch don't work
SCRATCH.Q2-A-1: If you're using Safari on macOS and the Scratch menus "File -> Load Project" and "File -> Save Project" menus aren't working, it might be that you're running in Safe Mode.
SCRATCH.Q2-A-2: Follow the instructions here for how to check and fix this.
SCRATCH.Q3: Machine learning classifier blocks in Scratch don't work
SCRATCH.Q3-A-1: Occassionally, the Scratch blocks for your machine learning model can lose the connection to the server. When this happens, they will stop returning results.
SCRATCH.Q3-A-2: You can check whether this has happened using the coloured status light in the "More Blocks" palette.
SCRATCH.Q3-A-3: If the status light next to your machine learning Scratch blocks is red, that normally means something is wrong. It might be a temporary problem. Try saving your project (using 'File' -> 'Save Project'), then refresh the browser page. If the status light goes green after the page reloads, you can load your project (using 'File' -> 'Load Project') to pick up where you left off.
SCRATCH.Q3-A-4: If the status light is still red after reloading the page, then there is probably something wrong with the machine learning model. Try going to the "Learn & Test" page for the project, which is where any error messages about your model can be found.
SCRATCH.Q3-A-5: If the status light next to your machine learning Scratch blocks is green, then the blocks should be working. If you're not getting the responses you expect from them, try going to the "Learn & Test" page and checking what results your model returns.
SCRATCH.Q5: Can I use any version of Scratch?
SCRATCH.Q5-A-1: You need to use the versions of Scratch that are provided by the Machine Learning for Kids site. They can be launched by clicking the Scratch, or 'Scratch 3', buttons from your project page.

TRAININGUI.TITLE: Training UI issues
TRAININGUI.Q1: Dragging images into training buckets (for image projects) doesn't work
TRAININGUI.Q1-A-1: Dragging images into the training buckets doesn't work if you're using Safari or Internet Explorer.
TRAININGUI.Q1-A-2: Sorry about this. If you can use another browser like Firefox or Chrome, please do that. Otherwise, you can click the "www" button and paste in the URL of training pictures instead.

MODELS.TITLE: Errors training machine learning models
MODELS.Q1: "No Watson credentials have been set up"
MODELS.Q1-A-1: Machine learning models in the tool are created using IBM Watson APIs.
MODELS.Q1-A-2: If you have an "unmanaged" class account, then your teacher or group leader will need to provide Watson API credentials from IBM Cloud for this to work. Step-by-step instructions for how they can do this are in the "Getting Started" document at the top of this page.
MODELS.Q2: "Watson credentials being used by your class were rejected"
MODELS.Q2-A-1: Machine learning models in the tool are created using IBM Watson APIs.
MODELS.Q2-A-2: If you have an "unmanaged" class account, then your teacher or group leader will have provided Watson API credentials from IBM Cloud for this to work (as described in the "Getting Started" document at the top of this page).
MODELS.Q2-A-3: However, the credentials that were provided are currently not working. The most likely reason is that the credentials were deleted from IBM Cloud since they were originally provided. If that isn't the case, the teacher or group leader who provided the Watson credentials needs to go back to the IBM Cloud dashboard to check the status of the Watson Assistant or Visual Recognition service that they created.
MODELS.Q3: "Watson Assistant API keys have no more workspaces available"
MODELS.Q3-A-1: Machine learning models in the tool are created using IBM Watson APIs.
MODELS.Q3-A-2: Watson Assistant (formerly Watson Conversation) credentials created by teachers have a limit on the number of machine learning models that they can be used to create. This is displayed in the IBM Cloud UI where the credentials were created, where they are called "workspaces".
MODELS.Q3-A-3: If this limit is exceeded, attempts to train new machine learning models will fail, and this message will be displayed:
MODELS.Q3-A-4: Your class already has created their maximum allowed number of models. Please let your teacher or group leader know that their "Watson Assistant API keys have no more workspaces available".
MODELS.Q3-A-5: If a student who has a successfully trained model then deletes their model, this will free up a workspace for use by another student.
MODELS.Q3-A-6: One way to avoid this error in future would be smaller class sizes. If there are fewer students than the number of workspaces supported by the Watson Assistant (formerly Conversation) credentials, then the limits will not be hit.
MODELS.Q3-A-7: Another way to avoid this error is to add additional Watson Assistant API keys to the class, or to use a Watson Assistant instance "plan" that has higher limits.
MODELS.Q4: "Watson Visual Recognition API keys have no more classifiers available"
MODELS.Q4-A-1: Machine learning models in the tool are created using IBM Watson APIs.
MODELS.Q4-A-2: Watson Visual Recognition credentials created by teachers have a limit on the number of machine learning models that they can be used to create. This is displayed in the IBM Cloud UI where the credentials were created, where they are called "custom classifiers".
MODELS.Q4-A-3: If this limit is exceeded, attempts to train new machine learning models will fail, and this message will be displayed:
MODELS.Q4-A-4: Your class already has created their maximum allowed number of models. Please let your teacher or group leader know that their "Watson Visual Recognition API keys have no more classifiers available".
MODELS.Q4-A-5: If a student who has a successfully trained model then deletes their model, this will free up a custom classifier for use by another student.
MODELS.Q4-A-6: One way to avoid this error in future would be smaller class sizes. If there are fewer students than the number of custom classifiers supported by the Watson Visual Recognition credentials, then the limits will not be hit.
MODELS.Q4-A-7: Another way to avoid this error is to add additional Watson Visual Recognition API keys to the class, or to use a Watson Visual Recognition instance "plan" that has higher limits.
MODELS.Q5: "Watson ... is currently rate limiting their API key"
MODELS.Q5-A-1: Machine learning models in the tool are created using IBM Watson APIs.
MODELS.Q5-A-2: If you have an "unmanaged" class account, then your teacher or group leader will need to provide Watson API credentials from IBM Cloud for this to work.
MODELS.Q5-A-3: If free accounts are created, they will apply a limit on the rate of requests for new machine learning models. In normal usage, this will not impact the class. However, if students get a "no more workspaces available" or "no more classifiers available" error (as described above) but then continue to click the "Train new Machine Learning model" button multiple times per second, for several minutes, then the rate limiting will apply.
MODELS.Q5-A-4: A message like this will be displayed to students in this case:
MODELS.Q5-A-5: Your class is making too many requests to create machine learning models at too fast a rate. Please stop now and let your teacher or group leader know that "the Watson Assistant service is currently rate limiting their API key"
MODELS.Q5-A-6: The rate limiting isn't applied by, or under the control of, the Machine Learning for Kids site. It is usually temporary, and is best resolved by waiting for a short time.
MODELS.Q5-A-7: If students are clicking the "Train new Machine Learning model" button and getting "no more workspaces available" or "no more classifiers available" errors (as described above), then they should be aware that repeatedly clicking the button will not resolve the issue, and will in fact make the situation worse for the rest of the class.
MODELS.Q6: I've been waiting for a model to train for ages!
MODELS.Q6-A-2: The page should check on the status of the machine learning model every 30 seconds, but very occassionally it stops checking, so you might be waiting for the model when it is actually ready for you.
MODELS.Q6-A-3: If it's been more than a few minutes, it's worth checking by refreshing / reloading the page.
MODELS.Q6-A-4: If it's been more than ten minutes, it might be worth considering restarting (click the Cancel button and then click the button to train a new machine learning model again).

TEACHERUI.TITLE: Teacher / Admin UI issues
TEACHERUI.Q2: Missing student account from the list in the teacher's page
TEACHERUI.Q2-A-1: User management for Machine Learning for Kids is implemented using the third party service, Auth0.
TEACHERUI.Q2-A-2: Occassionally, the list of students that Auth0 returns can get a little out of date, and fail to reflect students that have recently been created (or similarly, still show students that have been recently deleted).
TEACHERUI.Q2-A-3: In these instances, the students have normally been successfully created (or deleted) and it is just that the list of students being displayed doesn't reflect recent updates.
TEACHERUI.Q2-A-4: Auth0 will normally report such incidents on their status page as user indexing delays or problems with their Search API.
TEACHERUI.Q2-A-5: The best thing to do in these cases is to wait for the Auth0 indexing to catch up.
TEACHERUI.Q4: Why are machine learning models automatically deleted?
TEACHERUI.Q4-A-1: This was a feature requested by schools when Machine Learning for Kids was first developed. It came from the fact that there is a limit for how many machine learning models a class can have at any given time, and a need to make it easy to manage this limit.
TEACHERUI.Q4-A-2: Rather than requiring kids to have to clean up after a lesson and delete their models (in order to allow the next class to be able to create models), the tool can automatically clean up by deleting the models after the lesson is over. This makes it easy to run the next lesson, and the next lesson after that, without manual clean-ups in between.
TEACHERUI.Q4-A-3: The time limit before models are deleted is configurable. In a school, where lessons are 1 or 2 hours long, deleting models after two hours might be sensible. For a weekly coding club, six days might be a better fit to make sure that models are cleared up before each new club session.
TEACHERUI.Q4-A-4: To check the time limit for your class, visit the Restrictions section of your Teacher page.
TEACHERUI.Q4-A-5: To change the time limit for your class, please send me an email.
TEACHERUI.Q4-A-6: Note: Only machine learning models are automatically deleted, not the training data that was used to create them. So if a model is automatically deleted for a project that a student is still working on, they can always just click the "Train" button again to create the model again.

ACCOUNTISSUES.TITLE: Account issues
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q1: What is the difference between creating accounts or using "Try it now"?
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q1-A-1: Using "Try it now" to means there is no need to log on or create an account. There are no passwords for students to have to remember, and no need for teachers to have to provide personal information. It also saves teachers the time needed to manage student accounts.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q1-A-2: However, creating an account does enable additional features. Students can save their work and come back to it in a later lesson. They can work on a project together with other students in their class. They can log on from home and show their family what they've made.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q1-A-3: A summary of the differences is shown below:
ACCOUNTISSUES.TRAINMODELS: Train machine learning models to recognise...
ACCOUNTISSUES.USE_SCRATCH: Use machine learning models from Scratch
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q2: I've created a class account but my teacher's logon isn't working
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q2-A-1: You need to verify your email address before you'll be able to log on.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q2-A-2: When you created the class account, an email will be sent to the email address you provided, with a link to click on. If you click on that link, your email address will be verified and the class account will be activated. You should be able to log on now.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q2-A-3: If you haven't seen the verify email yet, make sure it's not gone into your spam folder.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q2-A-4: If you still can't find it, let me know and I'll try and help.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q3-A-2: Students cannot delete their own accounts.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q3-A-3: A teacher can delete a student account at any time by visiting the "Teacher" page  and clicking the "Delete student account" button next to the student account you want to delete.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q3-A-4: This will delete all information stored about that student and all of their projects and machine learning models.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q3-A-7: Deleting a teacher account will delete the entire class and all of the student accounts in it. It cannot be undone.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q3-A-8: This can be done by clicking the "Delete Class" button in the Advanced options section of your Teacher page
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q4: What information is stored about users?
